It is important to control bleeding quickly as it can become dangerous. When people lose a lot of blood as they could go into shock, which is life-threatening. Cuts can also get infected, and serious cuts may leave permanent damage, especially if not treated by a professional. 


Bleeding may also make the patient feel weak or faint, which could lead to them falling or injuring themselves. Large amounts of blood can also cause a slipping hazard to you, the patient and others. add and edit content directly in components.

8aa146cb-cbf8-4333-92e1-1b6edd1e618c.content:
Shock is not an emotional state, as many people think, it is a physical state and is life-threatening. It happens when vital organs in the body are not getting enough blood flow and can lead to them shutting down.


If someone goes into shock, you should call 999. Make sure they are laid down with their feet raised, and monitor their responsiveness and breathing. Keeping the casualty calm by reassuring them, and making sure they are wam with a blanket, will help.

What should I do?

  1. Wear gloves to stop your hands infecting the wound
  2. Do not take out any objects in the wound
  3. Use a dressing or clean blanket or cloth to put pressure on the wound and control the bleeding
  4. If the bleed is serious, call 999
  5. Help the casualty to lie or sit down
  6. Apply a secure dressing which does not cut off the circulation
  7. Monitor the casualty, raise the feet if the patient feels faint

Watch for signs of shock and prepare to treat an unresponsive casualty. If blood shows through the dressing, do not take off the original, apply another on top.
